bibl.title: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1940

div1.p: Hutchison provides details of the upcoming exercises honoring Lazear at Washington and Jefferson College and discusses Hench's presentation. Hutchison also provides information on Lazear's college career.

div1.head: Letter from Ralph Cooper Hutchison to Philip Showalter Hench, September 16, 1940

opener.dateline:
THE PRESIDENT'S OFFICE
WASHINGTON AND JEFFERSON COLLEGE
WASHINGTON, PENNSYLVANIA
September 16, 1940

div1.p:
Your good letter has come this morning and
I am delighted to have it. As usual your appreciation to
me is beyond anything which I have coming. However, I
am always glad to receive such credit whether I deserve
it or not and I can assure you that the joy of welcoming
you and giving you this degree will be one of the great
experiences of my life.

Now to answer the questions in your letter.
It is perfectly O.K. to write to Horace Davis whenever you
want to. He was delighted at the plan and approved it
enthusiastically.

Your invitation list could be longer than what
you suggest. Sometimes men in your position would invite
forty or fifty, and we are glad to invite them all.
It's good publicity for the college, and I should say any-
thing up to one hundred is perfectly one hundred per cent
O.K. I will appreciate it therefore if you will dig in
on that list and get it to us as soon as possible.

In regard to dates, the program now is as
follows. On Friday evening, October the twenty-fifth, at
about eight o'clock, the play “Yellow Jack”. The rest
of the program is on Saturday, October the twenty-sixth.
The exercises in the morning will be at ten o'clock I
should imagine. After that is an informal luncheon some-
where and then the game to which you are invited, but there
is no necessity of your going unless you want to. The
dinner will be in the evening at about six o'clock. So far
as this applies to your program I would answer your questions
as follows: there is no difficulty at all in your having
a dinner in Charlottesville on Thursday night, the twenty-
fourth and getting here in plenty of time for the play on
Friday night. So far as your staying at the hotel, that is
all right and we won't argue about that now. I haven't been
able to think that through. You could get out here from
your home if you wanted to stay at home. There will be no
difficulty about that. If, however, you prefer to stay at
the hotel here, that will be all right too. You can get
home Saturday night. The dinner will be over at about ten
o'clock and you could be home by eleven if you want to go
in to Pittsburgh.

I am glad to be warned about Moran and the
others. We will ask them to just give a greeting of
about two minutes at the dinner.

In regard to Doctor Cook, I think he also
should be invited. That will round out the party and make
it very nice. I will take care of that in the near
future.

I am not sure about the length of your talk
in the evening, or the use of pictures. Personally, I
find that pictures detract rather than add to a good
speech, and my guess is that the whole thing would be
easier for you if you did not attempt to use pictures
at this dinner. What do you think about this?

There is no reason why you should not write
to Doctor Sawyer at your convenience. I will try to get
a letter off to him soon. I suppose that as yet he does
not know what he is going to say. Personally my judgment
is that there is very little danger of your doing very
much overlapping even on so specific a subject. If I
were doing it I would try and plan my own speech and not
worry about the overlapping. You will hear his address
in the morning and any slight modifications you will make
quite naturally without advanced preparation.

I want to go back for a minute to the matter
of the length of your speech. I think you should have
more latitude, and I would suggest that you make it
somewhere between twenty and thirty minutes, not less than
twenty, not more than thirty.

Mrs. Lazear writes that she will be unable to
come. Her son writes that he will be unable to come.
Neither one of them give any reason. I presume that she
lacks the money, perhaps the health. He probably has to
stay on his job whatever that is.

If I were you I would secure as much information
as you can from Mrs. Lazear, but I would not give her a
chance to object to your telling anything you want to tell.
I would word your inquiries in such a way that she would
have no chance to object. A great deal of time has passed.
This is the time when Doctor Lazear should receive ample
credit and I would go ahead and say what you want to say
regardless of what she wants, particularly since she is not
coming. If she were to be here, it might be different.

Thank you for the suggestion about what we
shall do for Moran, Kissinger, and Doctor Cook if he comes.
I think something such as you suggest is the proper
solution and I will get into it just as rapidly as
possible and work something up. I believe that the
memorial minute, properly engraved and framed, would be
a better proposition than the key.
Give our love to Mary and the children.
div1.closer:
Affectionately yours, Hutch Doctor Philip S. Hench
Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
RCH/M
P.S. Doctor Lazear, I have just learned
for the first time, did not finish here.
He apparently attended here for threetwo years,
transferred to Hopkins, and was graduated there
with the B.S. degree. He was a member of the
Class of 1888 here. I have been confused on this
point myself up until this moment.
R.C.H.
